what: Set Up, Run, and Document Agent-Based Models (ABM) the Tidy Way
title: Set Up, Run, and Document Agent-Based Models (ABM) the Tidy Way
text: tidyABM designed streamline process setting , running, documenting Agent-Based Models (ABM) using principles tidy data. thus allows researchers easily organize, manipulate, visualize ABMs structured, coherent, intuitive manner, built tidyverse conventions efficiently build explore ABMs ensuring readability, reproducibility, transparency.

title: Set Up, Run, and Document Agent-Based Models (ABM) the Tidy Way
text: Currently, can install development version tidyABM like :
code: remotes::install_github('datenfruehstueck/tidyabm')

title: Set Up, Run, and Document Agent-Based Models (ABM) the Tidy Way
text: core, tidyABM organized environments agents. can characteristics (specified constants), variables (flexible attributions), rules (planned actions). set , many agents can added environment can simulated. Simulations work time , every tick (.e., one point time), variables rules agents overall environment evaluated. get started, set grid environment (.e., 2D rectangle). , also set/document seed random-number generation quite common thing ABMs. Next, create two kinds agents, orange ones violet ones. (, specifically: ) enjoy neighborhoods similar agents. Specifically, get unhappy one four direct neighbors similar . , tend check hood , ’s enough similarity, move places. Now let’s add agents environment. want several orange several violet ones. fact, ’d like ten . default, thereby randomly distributed across grid environment. Finally, need tell environment stop. Ideally, case every agent happy. ’s really possible, stop simulation 50 iterations (see ) latest see took us. Now can initialize environment look seminal distribution agents.  Next, let’s run simulation. can simply run one iteration (.e., one tick). , can iterate whole thing. case, iteration starts second tick already manually just done first one. iteration step takes . get status messages . also want take look visual development, can tell tidyABM also visualize iteration.     ’s done, tidyABM provides us statistics iteration. Oh, since ’s tidy package, course statistics come form tibbles. include meta information well. can also take look agents (two blueprints beginning added ones), also tidy format. ’s course explore possibilities huge, particularly flexible triangle characteristics, variables, rules. example, tidyABM capable handling grid environments also others environment comes helping utilities inform variables rules. Also, tidyABM can help write-ODD protocols. comes quite vignettes common ABM introductory simulations Schelling’s seggregation kind-looked .
code: library(tidyabm)  e <- create_grid_environment(seed = 826347,                              x = 10,                              y = 10) agent_o <- create_agent() %>%    set_characteristic(agent_group = 'orange') %>%    add_variable(is_unhappy = function(me, abm) {     neighbors <- grid_get_neighbors(me, abm, which = '+')     if (nrow(neighbors) == 0) {       return(FALSE)     } else {       return(sum(neighbors$agent_group == me$agent_group) == 0)     }   }) %>%   add_rule('move',            is_unhappy == TRUE,            .consequence = function(me, abm) {                spot <- grid_get_free_neighboring_spots(me, abm) %>%                  dplyr::slice_sample(n = 1)                grid_move(me, abm,                          new_x = spot$.x,                          new_y = spot$.y) %>%                  return()            })  agent_v <- agent_o %>%    set_characteristic(agent_group = 'violet',                      .overwrite = TRUE) #> Warning: The following characteristics already existed. They were overwritten: #> agent_group e <- e %>%    add_agents(agent_o,              n = 10) %>%    add_agents(agent_v,              n = 10) e <- e %>%    add_variable(share_unhappy = function(me, abm) {     abm %>%       convert_agents_to_tibble() %>%       dplyr::summarise(share_unhappy = sum(is_unhappy)/dplyr::n()) %>%       dplyr::pull(share_unhappy) %>%       return()     }) %>%     add_rule('stop when all are happy',              share_unhappy <= 0,              .consequence = stop_abm) e <- e %>%    init()  e %>%    visualize(color = agent_group) e <- e %>%    tick() #> [1] "Tick 1 finished in 0.426 secs:" #> [1] "  share_unhappy: 0.3" e <- e %>%    iterate(max_iterations = 30,           visualize = TRUE,           color = agent_group,           shape = is_unhappy) #> [1] "Tick 2 finished in 0.342 secs:" #> [1] "  share_unhappy: 0.25" #> [1] "Tick 3 finished in 0.273 secs:" #> [1] "  share_unhappy: 0.05" #> [1] "Tick 4 finished in 0.272 secs:" #> [1] "  share_unhappy: 0.05" #> [1] "Tick 5 finished in 0.255 secs:" #> [1] "  share_unhappy: 0" e #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   .tick share_unhappy .runtime       .n_agents_after_tick .finished_after_tick #> * <dbl>         <dbl> <drtn>                        <int> <lgl>                #> 1     1          0.3  0.4255121 secs                   20 FALSE                #> 2     2          0.25 0.3423042 secs                   20 FALSE                #> 3     3          0.05 0.2730961 secs                   20 FALSE                #> 4     4          0.05 0.2719679 secs                   20 FALSE                #> 5     5          0    0.2552781 secs                   20 TRUE                 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 10x10, 20 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 1 environment variable(s),  #> * 1 environment rule(s),  #> * ended after 5 ticks e %>%    convert_agents_to_tibble() #> # A tibble: 20 × 5 #>    .id   agent_group    .x    .y is_unhappy #>    <chr> <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <lgl>      #>  1 A1    orange         10     9 FALSE      #>  2 A2    orange          8     1 FALSE      #>  3 A3    orange          4     4 FALSE      #>  4 A4    orange          5     4 FALSE      #>  5 A5    orange          2    10 FALSE      #>  6 A6    orange         10    10 FALSE      #>  7 A7    orange         10     1 FALSE      #>  8 A8    orange          9     8 FALSE      #>  9 A9    orange          4     3 FALSE      #> 10 A10   orange          7     1 FALSE      #> 11 A11   violet          9     2 FALSE      #> 12 A12   violet          8     9 FALSE      #> 13 A13   violet          3     5 FALSE      #> 14 A14   violet         10     7 FALSE      #> 15 A15   violet          6     1 FALSE      #> 16 A16   violet          5     1 FALSE      #> 17 A17   violet          9     4 FALSE      #> 18 A18   violet          1     8 FALSE      #> 19 A19   violet          6     2 FALSE      #> 20 A20   violet          1     9 FALSE browseVignettes('tidyabm')

title: Set Up, Run, and Document Agent-Based Models (ABM) the Tidy Way
text: Feel free contribute package, either providing feedback (via issues) providing code (via pull requests). use package appreciate citing , example like : Haim, Mario (2023). tidyABM: Set , run, document agent-based models (ABM) tidy way. Source code releases available https://github.com/datenfruehstueck/tidyABM/.

what: Add agents to the environment — add_agents
title: Add agents to the environment — add_agents
text: Create agent first (create_agent). agent can seen blueprint. , use function add many replicates blueprint agent necessary. added independently interfere throughout runtime.

title: Add agents to the environment — add_agents
code: add_agents(.tidyabm, agent, n, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env add_agents(.tidyabm, agent, n, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env_grid add_agents(.tidyabm, agent, n, initial_position = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env_network add_agents(.tidyabm, agent, n, ...)

title: Add agents to the environment — add_agents
text: .tidyabm tidyabm_env object agents added agent tidyabm_agent object (blueprint) replicate n number agents style agent add ... arguments pass sub functions initial_position either NULL (default) agents placed randomly independent function two parameters (agent placed) abm (current environment previous agents already placed) gets called per agent place return vector length 2 interpreted x y coordinates (.e., c(x, y)). example position agents subsequent order via function: coordinate_counter <- c(0, 1) create_grid_environment(seed = 892, size = 3) %>% add_agents(create_agent(), n = 3, initial_position = \(, abm)  coordinate_counter[1] <- coordinate_counter[1] + 1 (coordinate_counter[1] > 3)  coordinate_counter[1] <- 1 coordinate_counter[2] <- coordiante_counter[2] + 1return(coordinate_counter) )

title: Add agents to the environment — add_agents
Add agents to the environment — add_agents
code: a1 <- create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 'young') a2 <- create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 'old') m <- create_grid_environment(seed = 1024, size = 50) %>%   add_agents(a1, 100) %>%   add_agents(a2, 100)

what: Add a rule (i.e., an action that is performed under certain conditions) — add_rule
title: Add a rule (i.e., an action that is performed under certain conditions) — add_rule
text: Rules checked executed per tick. Rules agents run rules environments. rule, ... conditions checked , prove valid, rule's .consequence run. Think rules code run within ABM. Rules establish connections abort , remove add agents, stop whole simulation make agents move. helping utilities (.e., readily implemented helpers used rules readymade consequences) examples, see full documentation, particularly per environment type.

title: Add a rule (i.e., an action that is performed under certain conditions) — add_rule
code: add_rule(.tidyabm, .label, ..., .consequence)  # S3 method for tidyabm add_rule(.tidyabm, .label, ..., .consequence)

title: Add a rule (i.e., an action that is performed under certain conditions) — add_rule
text: .tidyabm tidyabm object .label string describing rule ... <data-masking> expressions return logical value defined terms characteristics variables (tidyabm object rule applied ). multiple expressions included, combined & operator. .consequence function executed conditions apply. Use function two arguments, (tidyabm object specific point time) abm (whole tidyabm object). Note tidyabm_env objects two arguments tidyabm_agent objects different first () current agent second (abm) whole environment model. Importantly, changes apply function return updated (.e., tidyabm_agent object agent rules tidyabm_env object environment rules). function misses , changes ignored warning issued runtime. write functions need provide additional arguments functions, use style anonymized functions directly -line (function(, abm) ... return() \(, abm) ... return()).

title: Add a rule (i.e., an action that is performed under certain conditions) — add_rule
Add a rule (i.e., an action that is performed under certain conditions) — add_rule
code: create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 15) %>%   add_rule('minors move',            age >= 18,            .consequence = \(me, abm) {              spot <- grid_get_free_neighboring_spots(me, abm) %>%                dplyr::slice_sample(n = 1)              grid_move(me, abm,                        new_x = spot$.x,                        new_y = spot$.y) %>%                return()            }) #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>     age #> * <dbl> #> 1    15 #> # ABM agent #> * 1 agent characteristic(s),  #> * 0 agent variable(s),  #> * 1 agent rule(s),   create_grid_environment(seed = 1269, size = 5) %>%   add_variable(n_agents = \(me, abm) nrow(convert_agents_to_tibble(me))) %>%   add_rule('no more agents',            n_agents == 0,            .consequence = stop_abm) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 5x5, 0 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 1 environment variable(s),  #> * 1 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated

title: Add a flexible variable — add_variable
text: variable expected updated various () iterations. gets initiated start status quo model accessible throughout runtime. Compared characteristic, thus requires runtime resources flexibly updated every iteration.

title: Add a flexible variable — add_variable
code: add_variable(.tidyabm, ..., .overwrite = FALSE)  # S3 method for tidyabm add_variable(.tidyabm, ..., .overwrite = FALSE)

title: Add a flexible variable — add_variable
text: .tidyabm tidyabm object ... <data-masking> Name-value pairs. name gives name variable. avoid misunderstandings use unique variable names, also agents environments. Try also avoid starting name point/dot (.) internally added names use pattern. Good variable names also whitespace lowercase; use underscores separate words. recommended also avoid use minus signs. Hence, good variable name looks like this_is_a_great_name. value one : single value (e.g., character, numeric, logical, vector ...) function run every iteration modelling process Keep mind single values expected change, set_characteristic better-fitting method re-run every iteration modelling process. functions may use function gets called every iteration two arguments, (tidyabm object specific point time) abm (whole tidyabm object). Note tidyabm_env objects two arguments tidyabm_agent objects different first () current agent second (abm) whole environment model. write functions need provide additional arguments functions, use style anonymized functions directly -line (function(, abm) ... \(, abm) ...). .overwrite FALSE (default), variables name overwritten (warning issued)

title: Add a flexible variable — add_variable
Add a flexible variable — add_variable
code: create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 15) %>%   add_variable(share_same_age = function(me, abm) {                 neighbors <- get_neighbors(me)                 return(sum(neighbors$age == me$age)/nrow(neighbors))               }) %>%   add_variable(feels_welcome = \(me, abm) share_same_age >= .50) #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>     age #> * <dbl> #> 1    15 #> # ABM agent #> * 1 agent characteristic(s),  #> * 2 agent variable(s),  #> * 0 agent rule(s),   create_grid_environment(seed = 9896, size = 5) %>%   add_variable(m_age = \(me, abm) mean(convert_agents_to_tibble(me)$age, na.rm = T)) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 5x5, 0 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 1 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated

what: Convert the list of agent tidyabm_agent objects to a tibble — convert_agents_to_tibble
title: Convert the list of agent tidyabm_agent objects to a tibble — convert_agents_to_tibble
text: Returns tibble agents order agent objects initially added. Columns represent unique identifier named .id, agent characteristics, agent variables. , least one tick passed, agent variables NA. characteristics agents others NA agents share particular characteristic. Typically, characteristics/variables added internally particular environment prefixed ..

title: Convert the list of agent tidyabm_agent objects to a tibble — convert_agents_to_tibble
code: convert_agents_to_tibble(.tidyabm)

title: Convert the list of agent tidyabm_agent objects to a tibble — convert_agents_to_tibble
Convert the list of agent tidyabm_agent objects to a tibble — convert_agents_to_tibble
Convert the list of agent tidyabm_agent objects to a tibble — convert_agents_to_tibble
code: create_grid_environment(seed = 4583, size = 4) %>%   add_agents(create_agent(), 2) %>%   convert_agents_to_tibble() #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   .id      .x    .y #>   <chr> <int> <int> #> 1 A1        2     4 #> 2 A2        1     4

what: Convert current environment to tidygraph object — convert_network_to_tidygraph
title: Convert current environment to tidygraph object — convert_network_to_tidygraph
Convert current environment to tidygraph object — convert_network_to_tidygraph
code: convert_network_to_tidygraph(.tidyabm)

title: Convert current environment to tidygraph object — convert_network_to_tidygraph
Convert current environment to tidygraph object — convert_network_to_tidygraph
Convert current environment to tidygraph object — convert_network_to_tidygraph
code: a <- create_agent() %>%   add_rule('connect to a random other agent',            .consequence = \(me, abm) {              me %>%                network_connect(get_random_agent(abm, me)) %>%                return()            }) create_network_environment(seed = 183468,                            is_directed = TRUE) %>%   add_agents(a,              n = 5) %>%   init() %>%   tick() %>%   convert_network_to_tidygraph() #> [1] "Tick 1 finished in 0.157 secs" #> # A tbl_graph: 5 nodes and 5 edges #> # #> # A directed simple graph with 2 components #> # #> # A tibble: 5 × 1 #>   name  #>   <chr> #> 1 A1    #> 2 A2    #> 3 A3    #> 4 A4    #> 5 A5    #> # #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>    from    to #>   <int> <int> #> 1     2     1 #> 2     3     1 #> 3     1     2 #> # ℹ 2 more rows

code: create_agent()

what: Create an orthogonal grid environment — create_grid_environment
title: Create an orthogonal grid environment — create_grid_environment
text: Creates environment specified two-dimensional grid. Either define grid square setting one side's size define grid rectangle setting x y. seed used explicitly document random-number generation initiation script.

title: Create an orthogonal grid environment — create_grid_environment
code: create_grid_environment(seed, size = NULL, x = NULL, y = NULL)

title: Create an orthogonal grid environment — create_grid_environment
text: seed single number (integer) initiate random-number generation size number indicate side length square x numeric side length side x (omitted size set) y numeric side length side y (omitted size set)

title: Create an orthogonal grid environment — create_grid_environment
Create an orthogonal grid environment — create_grid_environment
code: create_grid_environment(seed = 42, size = 25) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 25x25, 0 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 0 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated  create_grid_environment(seed = 123, x = 25, y = 5) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 25x5, 0 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 0 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated

title: Create a network environment — create_network_environment
text: Creates environment without space limitations. However, agents therein can connect form network. seed used explicitly document random-number generation initiation script.

title: Create a network environment — create_network_environment
code: create_network_environment(seed, is_directed = FALSE)

title: Create a network environment — create_network_environment
text: seed single number (integer) initiate random-number generation is_directed true, connections/links network direction (.e., arrows); default FALSE

title: Create a network environment — create_network_environment
Create a network environment — create_network_environment
code: create_network_environment(seed = 43) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM network environment #> * undirected, 0 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 0 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated  create_network_environment(seed = 124, is_directed = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM network environment #> * directed, 0 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 0 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated

what: Distribute a given characteristic across a range of agents — distribute_characteristic_across_agents
title: Distribute a given characteristic across a range of agents — distribute_characteristic_across_agents
text: function allows set characteristic set agents needs initially dependent (e.g., normally distributed characteristic). just want set individual characteristic agents, use set_characteristic instead much faster.

title: Distribute a given characteristic across a range of agents — distribute_characteristic_across_agents
code: distribute_characteristic_across_agents(   .tidyabm,   .name,   .value,   ...,   .overwrite = FALSE,   .suppress_warnings = FALSE )  # S3 method for tidyabm_env distribute_characteristic_across_agents(   .tidyabm,   .name,   .value,   ...,   .overwrite = FALSE,   .suppress_warnings = FALSE )

title: Distribute a given characteristic across a range of agents — distribute_characteristic_across_agents
text: .tidyabm tidyabm_env holding (range ) agents .name character string representing name new characteristic .value vector length range agents single value (apply ) (anonymous) function called agent. functions may use function gets called every agent three arguments: (numeric iterator ranging 1 first agent n last agent), agent (respective tidyabm agent), agents (tibble resembling filtered agents distribution characteristic started filter expressions applied, see ...). function return one value characteristic, namely one current/respective agent. write functions need provide additional arguments functions, use style anonymized functions directly -line (function(, agent, agents) ... \(, agent, agents) ...). ... <data-masking> expressions return logical value defined terms characteristics variables added agents. specify agents get new characteristic. omitted, present agents receiving new characteristic. multiple expressions included, combined & operator. .overwrite FALSE (default), characteristics name overwritten (warning issued) .suppress_warnings TRUE, .overwrite yield warnings; default FALSE, though

title: Distribute a given characteristic across a range of agents — distribute_characteristic_across_agents
Distribute a given characteristic across a range of agents — distribute_characteristic_across_agents
code: create_grid_environment(seed = 168, size = 20) %>%   add_agents(create_agent(), 160) %>%   distribute_characteristic_across_agents(     'friend',     \(i, agent, agents) ifelse(stats::runif(1) > 0.5, i-1, 0)   ) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 20x20, 160 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 0 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated  a1 <- create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 'young') a2 <- create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 'old') m <- create_grid_environment(seed = 486, size = 50) %>%   add_agents(a1, 100) %>%   add_agents(a2, 100) %>%   distribute_characteristic_across_agents(     'opinion',     stats::rnorm(100),     age == 'old'   )

Take off and iterate — iterate
text: main function run model (.e., environment agents ). function just loop calls tick stop signal sent max_iterations limit reached. CAUTION: may take ! freshly init'ed environment starts first iteration, course. However, can also continue iterating model. model remembers tick stopped proceeds next time (see examples). information individual tick structured, see documentation .

title: Take off and iterate — iterate
code: iterate(.tidyabm, max_iterations = 50, verbose = TRUE, visualize = FALSE, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env iterate(.tidyabm, max_iterations = 50, verbose = TRUE, visualize = FALSE, ...)

title: Take off and iterate — iterate
text: .tidyabm tidyabm_env object max_iterations number iterations iterations stop (stopped earlier means convergence, e.g. environment rules). verbose TRUE (default), status message printed end visualize TRUE, tick ends visualization implemented respective environment; default FALSE ... arguments pass visualize

what: Spread a characteristic between source and its links — network_spread
title: Spread a characteristic between source and its links — network_spread
text: Spreading means certain information travels source_agent agents linked source. undirected environment, means agents linked source_agent receive characteristic given name (characteristic_name) given value (characteristic_value). directed environment, default, agents point current source_agent receive characteristic; behavior can changed via two arguments spread_via_indegree_links spread_via_outdegree_links.

title: Spread a characteristic between source and its links — network_spread
code: network_spread(   source_agent,   characteristic_name,   characteristic_value,   spread_via_indegree_links = TRUE,   spread_via_outdegree_links = FALSE,   overwrite = TRUE,   suppress_warnings = TRUE )

title: Spread a characteristic between source and its links — network_spread
text: source_agent agent information spread characteristic_name character string name characteristic set linked agent characteristic_value value spread information (.e., characteristic set) spread_via_indegree_links applicable directed graphs; true (default) information spreads via links source_agent target link (.e., others points) spread_via_outdegree_links applicable directed graphs; true information spreads via links source_agent also source link (.e., starting point arrow); default false overwrite argument passed set_characteristic (default true meaning target characteristic overwritten) suppress_warnings argument passed set_characteristic (default true meaning overwritten characteristic done silently/without raising warnings)

title: Spread a characteristic between source and its links — network_spread

text: data tibble particular_suffix string append main class tidyabm_env_ class_params list parameters initially relevant store class_suffix string suffix sub class name ; one   (empty), env, agent. particular_sub_class set character first class name use, even suffixed sub class name (NULL meaning particular sub class default)

title: Output constructor for tidyabm_env objects — new_tidyabm_env
text: tidyabm object optional subclass particular_sub_class subclass tidyabm_*suffix*

what: Extract compact information for an ODD protocol — odd
title: Extract compact information for an ODD protocol — odd
text: ODD (Overview, Design concepts Details) protocols suggested standard describing agent-based models (Grimm et al. 2006, 2010, 2020). Grimm et al. (2020) state, "ODD model descriptions (...) based written text intended read humans." function provides details environment agent specifications contain might relevant ODD written. returns 2020 ODD framework collected information pre-filled respective category.

title: Extract compact information for an ODD protocol — odd
code: odd(.tidyabm, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env odd(.tidyabm, ...)

title: Extract compact information for an ODD protocol — odd
text: .tidyabm tidyabm_env object ... arguments passed particular types environment

title: Extract compact information for an ODD protocol — odd
Extract compact information for an ODD protocol — odd
text: Grimm, V., U. Berger, F. Bastiansen, S. Eliassen, V. Ginot, J. Giske, J. Goss-Custard, T. Grand, S. Heinz, G. Huse, . Huth, J. U. Jepsen, C. Jørgensen, W. M. Mooij, B. Müller, G. Pe’er, C. Piou, S. F. Railsback, . M. Robbins, M. M. Robbins, E. Rossmanith, N. Rüger, E. Strand, S. Souissi, R. . Stillman, R. Vabø, U. Visser, & D. L. DeAngelis (2006). standard protocol describing individual-based agent-based models. Ecological Modelling, 198, 115-296. 10.1016/j.ecolmodel.2006.04.023 Grimm, V., U. Berger, D. L. DeAngelis, J. G. Polhill, J. Giske, & S. F. Railsback (2010). ODD protocol: review first update. Ecological Modelling 221, 2760-2768. 10.1016/j.ecolmodel.2010.08.019. Grimm, V., S. F. Railsback, C. E. Vincenot, U. Berger, C. Gallagher, D. L. DeAngelis, B. Edmonds, J. Ge, J. Giske, J. Groeneveld, . S. . Johnston, . Milles, J. Nabe-Nielsen, G. Polhill, V. Radchuk, M.-S. Rohwäder, R. . Stillman, J. C. Thiele, & D. Ayllón (2020). ODD Protocol describing agent-based simulation models: second update improve clarity, replication, structural realism. Journal Artificial Societies Social Simulation, 23(2), 7. 10.18564/jasss.4259

Remove a certain rule — remove_rule
code: create_agent() %>%   add_rule('minors move',            age >= 18,            .consequence = \(me, abm) {              spot <- grid_get_free_neighboring_spots(me, abm) %>%                dplyr::slice_sample(n = 1)              grid_move(me, abm,                        new_x = spot$.x,                        new_y = spot$.y) %>%                return()            }) %>%   remove_rule('minors move') #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM agent #> * 0 agent characteristic(s),  #> * 0 agent variable(s),  #> * 0 agent rule(s),   create_grid_environment(seed = 1271, size = 5) %>%   add_variable(n_agents = \(me, abm) nrow(convert_agents_to_tibble(me))) %>%   add_rule('no more agents',            n_agents == 0,            .consequence = stop_abm) %>%   remove_rule('no more agents') #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 5x5, 0 agents #> * 0 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 1 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated

Set an initial characteristic — set_characteristic
text: characteristic appended respective object right start. accessible throughout runtime can also change rule chooses . However, compared variable, calculated/determined iteration. need roll characteristic's distribution across range agents (e.g., characteristic supposed normally distributed across group agents), see distribute_characteristic_across_agents.

title: Set an initial characteristic — set_characteristic
code: set_characteristic(   .tidyabm,   ...,   .overwrite = FALSE,   .suppress_warnings = FALSE )  # S3 method for tidyabm set_characteristic(   .tidyabm,   ...,   .overwrite = FALSE,   .suppress_warnings = FALSE )

title: Set an initial characteristic — set_characteristic
text: .tidyabm tidyabm object ... <data-masking> name-value pairs. name lets identify characteristic. avoid misunderstandings use unique names, also agents environments. Try also avoid starting name point/dot (.) internally added names use pattern. Good names also whitespace lowercase; use underscores separate words. recommended also avoid use minus signs. Hence, good characteristic name looks like this_is_a_great_name. value treated single value (e.g., character, numeric, logical, vector ...). .overwrite FALSE (default), characteristics name overwritten (warning issued) .suppress_warnings TRUE, .overwrite yield warnings; default FALSE, though

title: Set an initial characteristic — set_characteristic
Set an initial characteristic — set_characteristic
code: create_grid_environment(seed = 3, size = 5) %>%   set_characteristic(condition = 'small') #> # A tibble: 0 × 0 #> # ABM grid environment #> * 5x5, 0 agents #> * 1 environment characteristic(s),  #> * 0 environment variable(s),  #> * 0 environment rule(s),  #> * not initiated  create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 15) #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>     age #> * <dbl> #> 1    15 #> # ABM agent #> * 1 agent characteristic(s),  #> * 0 agent variable(s),  #> * 0 agent rule(s),   create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(age = 15,                      gender = 'm') #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>     age gender #> * <dbl> <chr>  #> 1    15 m      #> # ABM agent #> * 2 agent characteristic(s),  #> * 0 agent variable(s),  #> * 0 agent rule(s),   create_agent() %>%   set_characteristic(embed_vector = c(23.2, 12.4, 4.2, -3.2, 13.2, -0.1)) #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>   embed_vector #> * <list>       #> 1 <dbl [6]>    #> # ABM agent #> * 1 agent characteristic(s),  #> * 0 agent variable(s),  #> * 0 agent rule(s),

Perform one single iteration — tick
text: single iterations following (order): randomize agent order go randomized agents ... . re-calculate agent variables (order added) b. check agent rules (order added) re-calculate environment variables (order added) check environment rules (order added)

title: Perform one single iteration — tick
code: tick(.tidyabm, verbose = TRUE, visualize = FALSE, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env tick(.tidyabm, verbose = TRUE, visualize = FALSE, ...)

title: Perform one single iteration — tick
text: .tidyabm tidyabm_env object verbose TRUE (default), status message printed end visualize TRUE, tick ends visualization implemented respective environment; default FALSE ... arguments pass visualize

title: tidyabm: Set Up, Run, and Document Agent-Based Models (ABM) the Tidy Way — tidyabm-package
text: tidyABM designed streamline process setting , running, documenting Agent-Based Models (ABM) using principles tidy data. thus allows researchers easily organize, manipulate, visualize ABMs structured, coherent, intuitive manner, built tidyverse conventions efficiently build explore ABMs ensuring readability, reproducibility, transparency.

what: Visualize an environment's current state — visualize
title: Visualize an environment's current state — visualize
text: Visualization highly depends particular type environment. grid environment, example, visualization resembles rectangle agents placed . function returns ggplot2::ggplot object, ready visualized/styled/manipulated.

title: Visualize an environment's current state — visualize
code: visualize(.tidyabm, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env_grid visualize(.tidyabm, color = NULL, shape = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for tidyabm_env_network visualize(.tidyabm, network_ggraph_layout = "kk", ...)

title: Visualize an environment's current state — visualize
text: .tidyabm tidyabm_env object ... arguments passed particular types environment color specify agent characteristic variable name color agents according specific characteristic/variable (default apply colors) shape specify agent characteristic variable name shape agents according specific characteristic/variable (default dots) network_ggraph_layout graphical layout use; see package ggraph details, fittingly/usually one 'kk', 'stress', 'fr', 'lgl', 'graphopt'

title: Visualize an environment's current state — visualize
Visualize an environment's current state — visualize
code: create_grid_environment(seed = 4583, size = 4) %>%   add_agents(create_agent(), 2) %>%   init() %>%   tick() %>%   visualize() #> [1] "Tick 1 finished in 0.002 secs"
